"Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge" is a game that has earned a reputation for being one of the most polarizing titles in the gaming world. While it is heavily criticized by some for its numerous 'flaws', players find unique charm and amusement in its quirks and unconventional design.

"Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge is a game that defies convention and embraces its eccentricity in a way that few other titles can match. While it's often cited as one of the worst games ever made, it's important to recognize the sheer audacity of its approach. This game is a masterclass in anti-design, turning traditional gaming norms on their heads.

The graphics in "Bad Rats" are reminiscent of a bygone era, evoking a sense of nostalgia for those who grew up in the early days of gaming. The simplicity of the art and animation harkens back to a time when games were created with limited resources, giving it a charming retro feel.

Gameplay in "Bad Rats" is anything but conventional. The puzzles are delightfully frustrating, with solutions that often seem counterintuitive. It's a testament to the game's unpredictability and refusal to conform to industry standards. It forces players to think outside the box and approach problems in unconventional ways.

The level design in "Bad Rats" is nothing short of chaotic, but that's part of its appeal. Each level is a rollercoaster of absurdity, where even the most carefully thought-out plans can go hilariously wrong. The game revels in its own absurdity and provides players with a unique challenge.

Sound and music in "Bad Rats" may not be top-tier, but they add to the game's overall charm. The repetitive soundtrack and quirky sound effects contribute to the game's offbeat atmosphere.

The user interface is a perfect reflection of the game's unconventional nature. It's clunky and confusing, but that's all part of the fun. The game's idiosyncratic approach to UI design is a breath of fresh air in a world of polished, cookie-cutter interfaces.

Replay value in "Bad Rats" comes from the sheer determination to conquer its enigmatic puzzles and unravel its peculiar logic. Each level provides a new opportunity for players to test the limits of their creativity and patience.

In summary, "Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge" is a game that marches to the beat of its own drum. It may not conform to traditional gaming standards, but for those who appreciate its eccentricity and embrace its flaws, it can be an extremely entertaining and memorable experience. If you're looking for a game that defies expectations and challenges your problem-solving skills in the most unconventional way, give "Bad Rats" a try. It's a testament to the diversity and creativity of the gaming world and an underappreciated masterpiece that deserve more credit for the impact on the gaming landscape it tries to make.

10/10

[h1]A Frustrating Romp: Bad Rats[/h1]

Rating: 6/9

Bad Rats, an enigma wrapped in a puzzle game, attempts to combine physics-based problem-solving with a macabre objective: killing a cat using a variety of rats and contraptions. Unfortunately, this bizarre concept is not enough to rescue the game from the depths of its own flaws.

[h2]Gameplay (2/10):[/h2]

The central premise of Bad Rats revolves around solving puzzles by deploying rats and their special abilities to eliminate a cat. In theory, this could be an amusing and quirky puzzle-solving experience. However, in practice, the execution is so flawed that it becomes infuriating. The physics engine often misfires, leading to outcomes that defy logic. A solution that should work may fail inexplicably, leaving players scratching their heads and cursing the game's inconsistencies.

[h2]Graphics and Sound (3/10):[/h2]

Visually, Bad Rats is nothing to write home about. The graphics are dated, with uninspired character designs and bland environments. The soundtrack is equally forgettable, providing little to no immersion or atmosphere. While graphics and sound are not the primary focus of puzzle games, their mediocrity adds to the overall disappointment of the experience.

[h2]Puzzles and Difficulty (2/10):[/h2]

The puzzles themselves vary in complexity, but their solutions are often far from intuitive. Players may find themselves resorting to trial and error due to the erratic physics engine. What should be a challenging yet rewarding puzzle-solving experience becomes an exercise in frustration, as progress feels more like luck than skill.

[h2]Replayability (1/10):[/h2]

Bad Rats offers little incentive for replayability. Once you've struggled through a level and witnessed its quirks and flaws, there's little motivation to revisit it. The lack of meaningful progression or engaging story also contributes to the game's overall lack of replay value.

[h2]Technical Issues (2/10):[/h2]

Beyond the physics-related problems, Bad Rats is plagued by technical issues. Bugs and glitches are not uncommon, further eroding any semblance of enjoyment that players might hope to find in this title.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]

Bad Rats, with its peculiar premise and frustrating execution, is a prime example of a game that fails to deliver on its potential. While it may appeal to those who enjoy bizarre and challenging puzzle games, its countless issues, ranging from problematic physics to a lack of polish, make it a hard sell for most gamers. Ultimately, it's a game that leaves players more irritated than entertained, making it difficult to recommend as a worthwhile addition to anyone's gaming library.

Even if the game was kind of frustrating it was still fun with couple of friends and after a few drinks and on top of that I got the game on heavy discount, so no hard feelings.

Bad Rats is a game that has a significant impact on the gaming community, providing an innovative gameplay experience, unique mechanics, and creative puzzles. The game is a physics-based puzzle game where players have to kill cats using a variety of objects like balls, explosives, and planks. Despite its seemingly macabre premise, the game's creativity and humor make it an enjoyable experience for players of all ages.

The game has a wide range of characters to choose from, each with its own unique abilities and specialties. These characters range from a suicidal rat who can detonate bombs to a mad scientist rat who can build complex machines to solve puzzles. The variety of characters encourages players to experiment with different strategies, adding to the replayability of the game.

Bad Rats' gameplay mechanics are simple yet challenging. The objective of the game is to kill the cats using the available objects in the environment. However, the game does not make it easy for players. The puzzles require careful planning, experimentation, and creativity to solve. This level of challenge makes the game incredibly rewarding when you finally succeed.

The game's graphics are simple yet charming. The cartoonish design of the characters and environments adds to the game's humorous tone. The sound design of the game is also excellent. The music is catchy and upbeat, and the sound effects complement the gameplay perfectly.

One of the standout features of Bad Rats is the user-generated content system. Players can create and share their own levels, adding to the game's replayability. This feature allows players to showcase their creativity and imagination and adds a level of community involvement to the game.

Playing Bad Rats has changed my life in many ways. It has helped me develop a sense of creativity and problem-solving skills that I have been able to apply to my personal and professional life. The game has taught me to approach problems from different angles, think creatively, and never give up on finding a solution.

Moreover, the game has helped me become more patient and persistent in my endeavors. The puzzles in Bad Rats can be frustrating, but the game rewards players who keep trying and don't give up easily. This lesson has carried over into other areas of my life, reminding me to stay committed and focused on my goals, even when facing setbacks or obstacles.

Overall, Bad Rats is an excellent game that provides an enjoyable, innovative, and challenging gameplay experience. The game's creative puzzles, unique mechanics, and humorous tone make it stand out from other puzzle games. The game has changed my life by teaching me valuable life lessons, improving my problem-solving skills, and helping me become a more patient and persistent person. I highly recommend Bad Rats to anyone looking for a fun and challenging puzzle game.

Another aspect of Bad Rats that I appreciate is its emphasis on creativity. The game rewards players who approach puzzles in unique and imaginative ways. This encouragement of creativity has inspired me to think outside the box and come up with unconventional solutions to problems in my personal and professional life. Bad Rats has taught me to not only think critically but also to think creatively, a skill that has proven invaluable in many situations.

Furthermore, the game's user-generated content system has allowed me to connect with other players and share my own creations. The ability to share levels with others and receive feedback has helped me improve my level design skills and encouraged me to continue exploring my creative side. I have met many fellow Bad Rats enthusiasts through the game's community forums and have made lasting friendships through our shared love of the game.

One of the most important ways that Bad Rats has impacted my life is through the sheer joy it brings me. The game's humor and charm never fail to put a smile on my face, and I have spent countless hours lost in the game's puzzles and world. Playing Bad Rats has become a form of stress relief for me, providing a welcome distraction from the pressures of everyday life. The game has taught me to embrace my playful and silly side, reminding me that it's okay to have fun and not take life too seriously all the time.

In conclusion, Bad Rats is a game that has had a profound impact on my life. It has taught me valuable lessons about creativity, problem-solving, and perseverance, and has helped me become a more patient and persistent person. The game's unique mechanics, creative puzzles, and charming humor make it a standout in the puzzle game genre, and its user-generated content system provides endless replayability. Playing Bad Rats has brought me endless joy and has become a cherished part of my life. I cannot recommend this game enough to anyone looking for a fun and rewarding puzzle game experience.

132706842.review:
Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge is a unique and entertaining puzzle game that is sure to provide hours of fun for players of all ages. The premise of the game is simple, you control a group of rats who are out for revenge against their feline enemies. The puzzle aspect of the game comes in as you try to come up with creative and effective ways to eliminate the cats using physics and functional objects.

One of the best things about this game is its humor. The game is filled with comedic moments and cartoonish violence, making it lighthearted and enjoyable to play. The game also has a good level of challenge, with 44 maps that range from easy to very hard. This gives players of all skill levels a chance to enjoy the game and make progress.

Another great feature of the game is its realistic physics simulation. The game offers a unique experience, where players can experiment with different solutions to each puzzle to find the quickest or most effective way to eliminate the cats. The 10 different specialist rats and 11 different deaths for the cats add to the game's replay value and overall enjoyment.

Overall, I highly recommend Bad Rats: The Rats' Revenge to anyone looking for a fun and entertaining puzzle game. The game offers a unique and humorous experience, challenging puzzles, and great replay value. If you're looking for a game that is easy to pick up and play, but difficult to put down, this is definitely one to consider.

127738836.review:
I picked up the bad rats series because I actually have a "Bad Game Collection". I actively hunt down to play some of the worst games out there and I was told this was "Without a doubt... he Worst game of all time". I find myself quite disappointed because not only is this not the worst game, it's full-on decent. Entirely forgettable and not must-play, but fully worth a 99 cent asking price.

This is basically a twist on the old series "The Incredible Machine" with a "Mouse Hunt" board game flavoring.  A cat has been trapped in a death machine and you need to build a rube goldberg contraption to trigger it. You'll be pushing the ball with the bulldozer rat, sending it flying with the baseball rat, or building makeshift catapults with the fat rat as a counterbalance. 

You have access to several types with rats each with fairly unique behaviors as well as a number of boxes, barrels, boards or other tools that can help you build you machine. Easier difficulties give you fewer tools to play with and a more details plan that will help you solve the level. Top difficulty and you're free to create the craziest murder machine you can think of. 

This is a relatively run of the mill puzzle game, except given an edgier concept. It's simplistic enough that it stays pretty lighthearted and the puzzles can be engaging enough... if a tad clunky on the execution. If you're in the mood for a machine building puzzle game or you have an irrational hatred for cats... this is a perfectly okay game.

127212296.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

122676973.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

118825904.review:
How exactly did I get my revenge you ask? Well, it's kind of a long story. It was a dark and stormy night. My mother and father were walking down the sidewalk with me. Our house was across the street. We started to cross together and made it halfway through, when suddenly we saw two bright white lights coming at us so fast that my father barely had enough time to push me across the street. All I heard was a loud *klunk*, then it all went black. I awoke and saw my mother and father soaked with blood in the middle of the street, while a big yellow cat with a scar over his left eye sped away faster than the speed of sound. After that night, I had devoted my life to get revenge by cleaning up all of the filth that was on the streets once and for all. I trained hard and recruited many fellow rats to fight for my cause.

We all had one enemy, the cats. We had all been dealing with them for way too long. They would threaten us, beat us, kill us, and they even took away the ones we loved. It was our time to shine. We loaded up with cannons, bows and arrows, baseball bats, and even vacuums. We were ready to clean up all of the trash on our streets once and for all. The first cat was tough to kill, since we had no idea what we would be up against. We lost Jerry and Milton in the process, but we all knew what was on the line in order to exterminate all of the cats. After the 10th cat, we didn't even pay attention to the ones that had died because we had become used to it. After 20, it seemed that some were just killing the cats for sport. The 30th cat was a bit stronger. It had wiped out over half of our entire army, but Crazy Steve strapped on his vest and let himself get swallowed, where he detonated the cat and saved many of our lives that day.

I will never forget the sacrifice he made. It was a rough day. Cat 39 had killed all but 8 of us. There was only one left. The next day, I saw him. He had a scar. It was him. It was the one who had killed my parents. I had trained my whole life for this moment. I had done everything I could to get the revenge I wanted. It was my moment. The first rat had blown himself up, along with the second rat. The third rat ran right into the cat and was devoured almost instantly. The fourth rat shot his bow and arrow straight up into the air and it went straight through his skull. The fifth rat had fallen on the sixth rat and crushed him, then was ran over by the seventh rat's bulldozer, who then was blown up by the sixth rat's bomb vest. It was just me. Me against the one who had killed my family. The one who had taken everything away from me when I was a child. The one who ruined my life and the sole reason of my hatred for cats. That didn't matter anymore. All I wanted was my revenge. I took the seventh rat's bulldozer, and I went full speed right up the cat's pooper. With my bomb vest on, I drove up as far as I could. I drove through his intestines and all around. I did all I could do in order to win. I didn't care anymore. I was almost there. I could almost taste the sweet revenge. I strapped the vest to the cat's heart, drove as fast as I could out of the cat's mouth. I was on his tongue when the blast went off. I was launched out of his mouth, and I watched as his eyes popped out of his skull and his head exploded and his guts went everywhere. I was soaked in blood and with a smile on my face, I said, "Many before me have tried, but only the baddest will succeed."

TL;DR
Only in your darkest hours, can you finally become a Bad Rat.

118442039.review:
"Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge" is a once-in-a-lifetime gaming experience that entices the player to levels beyond comprehension. A true masterpiece. 43 perplexing and unique levels lie between you and becoming the "baddest rat", any rational human should strive to earn such a prestigious title. Integrates interesting and abstract puzzles whilst still maintaining a simplistic and beautiful gaming loop. Not only has “Bad Rats” provided me with the best hours of my life, but it has also advanced my philosophical thinking. This game has given me a new outlook on the intricacy and cunning of rodents, how they can also have aspirations, professions, and a greater sense of meaning. Character design is flawless, with household favourites such as: bomber rat, lung rat and fat rat. Each character adds a new "dimension" to the level layouts, making every puzzle contain a seemingly endless number of solutions. What is there not to love about this game?! The physics engine feels refined and has little to no flaws. Events are slightly randomised for double the fun, so that the exact same solution would only work half the time! Genius! Literal and utter perfection.
Recommended for all ages.

118128460.review:
Picture this; you open up Steam and browse your library endlessly, unable to find something to do. You then spend 30 minutes opening and then closing various games, maybe open Youtube, expecting your reccomended to be any different than it was 10 minutes ago. This is a situation many of us get trapped into, and a game would fix that.  More specifically; Bad Rats: The Rat's Revenge. Bad Rats: The Rat's Revenge is a game of all time. It has graphics, puzzles, and sound design. In this essay I will be examining what makes this game notable.

This game really has gameplay. In BRTRR, you play as a group of rats plotting ways to murder, or 'Troll', a helpless cat. You do this by arranging various building blocks and mice in a way to press a certain object, killing the cat. The rats each have different abilites and ways of pushing the building blocks and the 'ball', which is the only object that can press the aforementioned object. You will be arranging the objects and rats in a way to push the 'ball' to it's desired location. It also has the only physics engine in gaming where doing the same thing twice yields different results, creating emmergent and diverse gameplay. This makes the puzzles. There are 30+ levels to complete with additional modes. Complete each level to achieve a 'Victory Royale'. Each puzzle also has more than one solution, creating replay value. There are also steam achievements. To quickly sum up what each rat and object does, the:

- Baseball rat. This is the first rat you'll use. He uses his baseball bat to hit any and every object/rat in front of him. This can knock it far away or kill it if it's a rat. His famous catchphrase is "Its rattin time".

-Archer rat. He shoots an arrow, hitting objects or rats from a distance. The effect is the same as the Baseball rat's bat.

-Fat rat. By far my favorite, this rat is really fat. This is a reference to your mom. This rat does nothing and is only used for weighing things down, also like your mom.

-Bomber rat. This rat is a muslim suicide bomber (not joking). He will blow himself up once something gets close to him, having a similar effect to the baseball rats bat, but it affects everything in radius.

-Tractor rat. This rat operate the slowest fucking vehicle ever, and moves 0.0000001 feet a second in order to push objects. I rarely use him.

-Canon rat. This rat shoots himself out of a canon.

-Firework rat. This rat is tied to a firework and has does the same exact thing as the canon rat.

-Suck rat. He sucks things with his sucker, can create a stream of air in order to propel objects upward.

-Hamster wheel rat. he sits in a hamster wheel and will run, speeding up objects going on him. He also appears in one level.

-Lung rat. This rat is a heavy smoker (reference to your dad), and uses his smoking power to blow objects away. Literally just the archer rat but with an anoying wheezing sound. His famous catchphrase is "its blowin time"

Getting into the objects:

-Plank. Can act as a bridge.

-Balloon. I see this in nearly every puzzle but have no clue what its used for. It just floats up and eventually offscreen.

-Umbrella. Can be tied to objects to slow their fall speed.

-Barrel. Plank but smaller.

-Crate. Barrel but smaller.

To wrap up the gameplay section; the diversity in rats and objects creates a gameplay loop. Now onto graphics.

This game has very graphics. Honestly that's all I can say.

This game has audio. I hope you like listening to the same 2 songs on loop!

In conclusion, this game is very notable as one of the first strand type games, it has earned 10 Ratrillion dollers and inspired future successes such as Death Stranding and the Fianl Fantasy 7 Remake's side quests. 100/10 would rat again.

115433807.review:
Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge is a triumphant exploration of the lengths that an oppressed group will go to overthrow their oppressors, as well as the cascading influence for change that their actions often have on those involved. The game's story weaves a brilliant narrative tapestry following a fragmented population of rats using everything they have at their disposal to topple the figurative tower of systematic oppression leveraged upon them by the rule of the cat establishment. With each consecutive victory the rats grow in number and strength, as they are forced to devise increasingly complex tactics to maintain their onslaught of victories against the cat menace.

A lesser game may stop here, but Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge however, takes a unflinching look at the deeper moral implications of such a conflict. The inspiration the game takes from the work of Nietzsche is quite apparent. To quote Nietzsche directly, “He who fights with monsters should be careful lest he thereby become a monster. And if thou gaze long into an abyss, the abyss will also gaze into thee.” This theme of corruption of morality is clearly displayed through the sheer brutality of the Rats' actions. Thus where the moniker of "Bad Rats" finds it origin. A noble race of rats driven to horrendous acts in the name of the greater good, and at the cost of their own sacred purity.

Any game capable of balancing such complex and emotionally poignant themes so eloquently is well deserving of praise and economic success, but a game that manages this in addition to providing such brilliant AAA quality gameplay deserves to be forever exalted is the halls of gaming history. This is not to mention to the incredibly reasonable price at which this game is offered.

Needless to say I rate this game as a perfect 10/10, and as an absolute MUST buy for any self respecting gamer!

113449299.review:
This game is simply the pinnacle of amazing game design. The physics are near perfect and the gameplay never gets repetitive. Every second I play this game I feel nothing but pure bliss.

The concept alone is enough for me to recommend this game. The pure earthshattering creativity that this game displays might be overwhelming to you at first, but trust me, once you get used to it you will never look at the world in the same way again. This game takes the classic duo of cat and rat, but instead of the cat hunting the rat... IT IS THE OTHER WAY AROUND! I cannot get over it! You play as RATS to kill CATS using BOMBS and MICROWAVES. Truely marvellous.

This game features multiple world famous gaming icons that rival the likes of Mario Mario, Master Chief, Cooking Mama and Pikachu. My favorites of these stunning characters have to be Bomb Rat, Fat Rat and Breath Rat. With household names like these being included, you expect a top quality game and I can confidently say that this masterpiece does not disappoint.

On top of that, this game's visuals are simply stunning. Rarely do I start up a game to simply gaze at its wonderful menu screen but Bad Rats has me doing this time and time again. This game doesn't just look good. No, it is a treat to the eyes, like a warm, soft rat is hugging your eyeballs. Often I just close my eyes to image what it would be like to live in the beautiful world of Bad Rats. I dream about it. I long for it. I cannot get enough of it.

This stunning game has one more trick up its sleeve. If you (rightfully) thought a game of this caliber would have a pricetag near the thousands of euros, you are gravely mistaken. This game costs no more than 99 cents. When I learned of this fact my mind was BLOWN. To this day I cannot believe it and it shocks me everytime I look at the pricetag. What a deal.

So, do I recommend this game? How could I not. In my opinion there is not a single game on this planet that comes close to the grandness of Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge. I'd even go so far as to say that this is the PERFECT game.

1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil

2 yellow bell peppers, diced into 1/2-inch pieces (about 2 cups) 

1 large yellow onion, diced into 1/2-inch pieces (about 2 cups) 

Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper 

1 large eggplant (1 1/2 pounds), diced into 1/2-inch pieces (about 9 cups) 

1 large zucchini (1 pound), diced into 1/2-inch pieces (about 3 1/2 cups) 

3 cloves garlic, minced (about 1 tablespoon) 

3 tablespoons tomato paste 

1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, optional 

1 1/2 pounds ripe tomatoes, diced into 1/2-inch pieces (about 4 cups) 

1/2 cup fresh parsley, chopped, plus more for serving 

6 large fresh basil leaves, torn, plus more for serving 

"Heat 1/4 cup olive oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat until shimmering, about 1 minute. Add the bell peppers, onion and 1 teaspoon salt and cook, stirring often, until the onions are translucent and the bell peppers have softened slightly, about 10 minutes. Add the eggplant, the remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil and 1 teaspoon salt. Cook, stirring often, until the eggplant is very soft, about 8 minutes. Add the zucchini and continue to cook, stirring often, until beginning to soften, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic, tomato paste and red pepper flakes, if using. Cook, stirring often, until the zucchini has softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the tomatoes, bring to a simmer and then reduce the heat to low and cover the pot. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until the ratatouille has reached a thick stew-like consistency, about 10 minutes. Stir in the parsley and basil with salt and pepper to taste. Spoon into a bowl and sprinkle with more fresh parsley and basil before serving."

Source: https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/food-network-kitchen/ratatouille-5658876

109691577.review:
The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.
The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

We are defined by our experiences and how they shape and mold us. Time is a sculptor on our souls as we navigate the human condition. We share our firsts, our achievements, our failures, our moments of strength and weakness.  We will often encounter creations, man-made or of God Himself, that leave us in awe, whose splendor and beauty leave an impression upon us so profound that our souls are irrevocably altered. One such creation is the 2009 computer entertainment software package, Bad Rats.

Upon starting this game, we are greeted with artwork so moving and compelling, we feel the hand of God guide us through each visually stunning level. Although we know the game is of man, we feel divine intervention within. Hours seem to pass like seconds, sand through our fingers, as we navigate intellectually stunning courses and weep, yes weep, with joy upon guiding the rats to their noble cause. It is an experience that will allow the blind to see and force the sinner to atone. So I hope that you, dear player, find salvation for your troubled soul within the beauty and splendor that is...... BAD RATS

109162100.review:
In many ways, the work of a critic is easy. We risk very little, yet enjoy a position over those who offer up their work - and their selves - to our judgement. We thrive on negative criticism, which is fun to write and to read. But the bitter truth we critics must face is that in the grand scheme of things, the average piece of junk is probably more meaningful than our criticism designating it so.


But there are times when a critic truly risks something - and that is in the discovery and defence of the New. The world is often unkind to new talent, new creations. The New needs friends. Last night I experienced something new: an extraordinary meal from a singularly unexpected source. To say that both the meal and its maker have challenged my preconceptions about fine cooking is a gross understatement.
They have rocked me to my core.

In the past, I have made no secret of my disdain for Chef Gusteau's famous motto; "anyone can cook." But I realise, only now do I truly understand what he meant. Not everyone can become a great artist, but a great artist can come from anywhere. It is difficult to imagine more humble origins than those of the genius now cooking at Gusteau's - who is, in this critic's opinion, nothing less than the finest chef in France!

I will be returning to Gusteau's soon - hungry for more.

106871435.review:
Bad Rats critiques industrialization by showing us that with the tractor rat, machines and mechanized warfare brings nothing but death, this is also shown by the wheel rat, who spins around in a metal wheel and propels the ball forward to kill the cat. 

The wheel rat could also be seen as a critique on nationalism and propaganda because in the act of running in the metal wheel he continuously rips and hurts himself for his country/nation.


Not only can Bad Rats be seen as a critique of what I mentioned above, but it also critiques communism because in the Russian Revolution from 1917-1923 the Bolsheviks revolted against the autocrats that dictated Russia at the time because in the game you can see many lesser rats attempting to kill and/or overthrow the cats. This could be seen as a critique because 7-12 million people were killed during the Russian Revolutionary War, only to prop up another totalitarian dictatorship that killed many more people and set up many other communist dictatorships that still exist today, such as China and North Korea.


The way that Bad Rats criticize capitalism is much more subtle, but the message is still there, in the act of buying weapons and vehicles from other rats, they are making those rats get rich off of the back of a terrible conflict.


If you look at the game in a different light when you could see the rats genociding the cats rather than fighting them or revolting against them. Fascism is a form of extreme nationalism and forcefully suppresses any form of opposition, so it could be the cats protesting against the authoritarian rats.

so in summry bad rat equal good game

106597806.review:
[h1]Bad Rats: The Rat's Revenge / Malas Ratas: La Venganza de las Ratas[/h1]
¿Nunca te habías preguntado que pasaría si los ratones se vengarán de su mayor depredador con la mayor cantidad de gore y puzzles posibles? Pues aquí esta el juego perfecto para ti en esta gran aventura de puzzles con físicas y ratones muy violentos y dispuestos a sacrificarse para cumplir el sueño de desaparecer a los gatos de la fas de la Tierra.
[h1]Lo Bueno:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Precio más que asequible con la cantidad de horas que puedes pasarte en sus más de 40 niveles.[/b]
[*][b]Diseño de niveles y gameplay muy intuitivo y bien pensado, te hará pensar mucho. Además de su gran [b]Originalidad[/b] que dejará completar los mapas con más de una solución.[/b]
[*][b]Sus gráficos no son los mejores [spoiler]Es viejo ¿Que te esperas?[/spoiler] Pero cuando vamos a hablar de la muerte del gato... ¡Wow! eso si es un festín de sangre.[/b]
[*][b]Los controles y físicas del juego son muy buenas.[/b]
[*][b]Tiene opción de tabla de clasificación virtual donde puedes competir con tus amigos y internautas para ver cuantos puntos puedes conseguir y insentivar el que vuelvas a jugar.[/b]
[/list]
[h1]Lo Malo:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Hay poca variedad de opciones y las que hay no cambian mucho la estética o el rendimiento ([i]Que es muy bueno obviamente...[/i])[/b]
[*][b]Hay un bug que no se como sale ni como arreglar donde en medio del gameplay el cursor toma la forma de las dos flechas unidas para mover un objeto pero no puedes tocar nada ni abrir el menú de opciones, por lo que tienes que reiniciar el juego para continuar.[/b]
[*][b]El sistema de Contraseñas es muy viejo y poco intuitivo, estaría mejor que pusieran un menú completo con todos los mapas de forma gráfica.[/b]
[/list]
[quote=Marloncha]RATAS.... ¡AL ATAQUE![/quote]

106520517.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

105759366.review:
DO YOU LIKE RATS TOO?????!!!?!?!?!? HERE ARE 10 RAT FACTS SO YOU CAN EZ BEAT THIS GAME

1.  Rats Can Swim
Believe it or not, rats could give Michael Phelps a run for his money. Certain types of rats can tread water for up to three days and hold their breath for three minutes. Additionally, some species can swim over a mile. And the stories about rats popping up in toilets is no urban legend. They can easily make their way up your pipes.

2. Rats Are Revered in Some Cultures
A temple dedicated to Hindu goddess Karni Mata in northwest India is home to more than 15,000 rats. These rodents are worshipped and protected, and human devotees of the temple believe that when they die, they will be reincarnated as rats.

3. Their Tails Keep Them Cool
Rats don’t sweat like humans, nor do they pant to relieve the heat like a dog. Rather, rats control their body temperature by expanding and contracting the blood vessels in their tails.

4. A Rat’s Teeth Never Stop Growing
Rats are known for gnawing on things, and with good reason. Their teeth can grow up to 5 inches per year. They have to chew on things to wear them down. In addition to wood, rats can also gnaw through lead, cinder blocks and aluminum sheeting.

5. There Are Many Different Types of Rats
Most people have heard of Norway rats (brown rats), pack rats and roof rats (black rats). However, what many people don’t know is that there are 56 known species of rats in the world.

6. Some Rats Get Pretty Big
True there are some big rats out there rummaging through garbage cans, but the types of rats most people are used to seeing are small compared to some of their more massive rodent relatives. The Sumatran bamboo rat, for example, can weigh up to 8.8 pounds and measure 20 inches in total length. That’s the size of a small housecat. While not as heavy at 3 pounds, the Gambian pouched rat can measure as long as 3 feet from nose to tail.

7. Rats are Prolific Breeders
One of the facts about rats that most people are familiar with is that they can breed quickly. A female rat can reproduce every three weeks or so. And when she gives birth, the litter typically contains six to 10 pups. These pups become sexually mature when they’re three to four months old, meaning they can begin spawning their own broods.

8. They’re Social Creatures
Most types of rats live in communities, in which they groom each other, sleep together and even play. However, they are territorial, so they can turn aggressive toward unfamiliar rats. A group of rats is called a “mischief.”

9. Rats Can Carry Pathogens That Spread Disease
Yes. One of the most well-known facts about rats is that they can carry pathogens that spread diseases that can affect humans. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), rats and mice can spread over 35 diseases. They’re even responsible for an outbreak of monkey pox in 2003.

10. Rats Can Laugh
When rats play, they experience what researcher Jaak Panksepp calls a type of “social-joy.” The result? They laugh, albeit not a hearty chuckle like you’d hear from a human. Instead, they emit a high-pitched chirping noise.

Now that you know these facts about rats, you can see why some people might keep them as pets. Nonetheless, that doesn’t mean you ever want to encounter a wild rat in your house or workplace. That’s why it’s important to know how to keep rats away.

Bad Rats. Let me ask you a question, what is Bad Rats? Bad Rats is… how do I put this into words… a game that every company strives their games to become. Bad Rats is the prime example of what a game truly should be.

Bad Rats, developed by Invent4, a game company that we all know and love, was developed in humanity’s overall peak, July 20, 2009. July 20, 2009 is celebrated by many as “The Day of the Rats.” 

No more about talking how good Bad Rats is, I’m sure you’re all eager on WHY it’s the best creation man could ever think of. The Mona Lisa is only child’s play to what Bad Rats has to offer.

Why don’t we begin with the visuals. The visuals of Bad Rats is clearly ahead of time. Scientists from Harvard have conducted studies that because of how immersive Bad Rats is, one can simply unlock the 4th dimension by playing “Bad Rats.” A quote from Thomas Jefferson once said, “damn this shit be bussin lmao.” If you think modern triple A games such as Call of Duty: Cold War is “one of the best visually looking games,” then I have nothing to describe Bad Rats. I bought a rat from my local PetSmart and compared it to Bad Rats. I could swear that the rats from Bad Rats just look more visually accurate than my rat.

One must ask, “if Bad Rats looks so good that it allows players to unlock the 4th dimension, how can I run it?” Luckily for you, the developers of Bad Rats are no clowns. It’s requirements are so minimal, that I have overclocked my rock in which I’ve obtained in my backyard to run Bad Rats in 60k resolution all in “big rats settings,” the highest one can put it to be and in 400 frames per second. I don’t know how a game could look stunningly amazing and be able to run on everything, but the developers of Bad Rats just know what they’re doing.

Enough about the visuals of Bad Rats, let’s talk about the actual gameplay and story. The story of Bad Rats is just better than all the games combined and very simple. Just kill the cat. Remember, sometimes simplicity is just better. The puzzles that Bad Rats has to offer is ahead of everyone. I quote from the man itself, Albert Einstein, “bro wtf is this shit I can’t do jack.” If Einstein is incapable of solving such complicated puzzles, then how did the developers finish it? Simple. They didn’t. They’re simply waiting for super humans to exist to finish the game for them. How brilliant. Michael Jackson, a student from Stanford with a PHD in rats said that, “if you wish to feel dumb, simply walk into the room where the Bad Rats developers are.” After conducting multiple surveys, Mrs. Jordan has figured out that the average IQ of a Bad Rats developer is within the thousands. 

In conclusion, Bad Rats is a game way ahead of its time. I highly recommend everyone to try the game as it’s as cheap as something from the dollar tree and visually stunning. I highly recommend all users to buy multiple copies and start to spread it like the novel Sars2 COVID-19. I surely believe that by spreading Bad Rats, the word’s average IQ would rise by 100.

96659207.review: In many ways, the work of a critic is easy. We risk very little, yet enjoy a position over those who offer up their work and their selves to our judgment. We thrive on negative criticism, which is fun to write and to read. But the bitter truth we critics must face, is that in the grand scheme of things, the average piece of junk is probably more meaningful than our criticism designating it so. But there are times when a critic truly risks something, and that is in the discovery and defense of the new. The world is often unkind to new talent, new creations. The new needs friends. Last night, I experienced something new: an extraordinary meal from a singularly unexpected source. To say that both the meal and its maker have challenged my preconceptions about fine cooking is a gross understatement. They have rocked me to my core. In the past, I have made no secret of my disdain for Chef Gusteau's famous motto, "Anyone can cook." But I realize, only now do I truly understand what he meant. Not everyone can become a great artist; but a great artist can come from anywhere. It is difficult to imagine more humble origins than those of the genius now cooking at Gusteau's, who is, in this critic's opinion, nothing less than the finest chef in France. I will be returning to Gusteau's soon, hungry for more.

96278725.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 60.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realise that.

Thank you

96224653.review:
Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge and its successor, Bad Rats Show are more than mere games. They are art, in the truest and most pure meaning of the word. On my first (of many!) playthrough of the game, I lost the final level by letting the countdown end, simply because I was to distraught at the knowledge that once I beat it, I would never be able to experience any part of Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge for the first time ever again. When I finally beat it, I sobbed for hours without end, and once I had finished that, I opened up a new game of Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge, to go through the absolute majesty of it all over again.

I cannot recommend Bad Rats: the Rats' Revenge enough. It is something for everyone; the casual gamer, the hardcore gamer, the racist, and even the woman.

100/10

92643003.review:
Bad Rats is a revolutionary first person shooter that sets a new standard for this era of gaming. This is game published by Electronic Arts and is developed by Dice on the new Frostbite 4 engine to provide a superior graphic fidelity compared to other marvellous titles including Crisis 3. The story of the game takes place in the year 2035 when North Korea officially ends the cease fire for the Korean War and launches a series of surprise attacks on the United States of America and South Korea. North Korea launches an overwhelming amount of long range ballistic missiles towards major metropolitan areas in the United States which devastates the population and cripples the infrastructure of the government to be able to function properly to contain control of the United States. North Korea launches a full scale aerial campaign on Seoul with a relentless wave of troops pouring across the DMZ of North Korea and South Korea. China and the rebuilt Soviet Union organized by Vladimir Putin has been supplying North Korea with highly advanced military technology and expertise has secretly been supporting North Korea for a war since 2006! You play as a squad in the Navy Seals for the United States called “Bad Rats” Your objective is to assassinate all cats in the region of Asia to cut off all food supplies from the North Koreans and collapse the regime of Kim Jong Un. Using the destructible environments from the Frostbite 4 engine you must use the environment for a tactical advantage to exterminate all cats from Asia. Fan favourite maps return including Seige of Shainghai where you must collapse a skyscraper to kill all cats in the building. Facial scanning technology from LA Noire returns to add an extra layer of realism with realistic facial animation movements to add more emotion to the already immersive world. This is a highly addicting shooter that takes place in locations across the world from nuclear wasteland America to the glorious lands of North Korea. You have a massive arsenal of over 500 weapons to use with thousands of gadgets and gun camouflages. Bad Rats is integrated with the Steam Workshop which has created thousands of community maps and gun skins to be submitted into the game for future free DLCs called “Operations”. Each operation adds an extra layer of immersion into the game with a huge variety of community maps and skins to be added to expand the already masterpiece of a game. Bad rats is a very skill based shooter and requires extensive training to truly shine in multiplier. Bad Rats is the only first person shooter on the market to add a innovative competitive mode with ranks to determine your skill level. In multiplayer there are 2 teams. Counter Cats and Cats. The counter cats must plant a bomb on one of the two locations on the map to kill the population of cats in the area. The cats must prevent the counter cats or the “bad rats” from planting the bomb by either killing all the Counter Cats or defusing the bomb to save the population of cats in the premise.Bad Rats is a highly addicting shooter that any seasonal gamer should try out but I assume you already have! Bad Rats global sales have exceeded 1 billion on the first day outselling the Call of Duty franchise. It is very rare to see game a game this flawless since the release of Half Life 2. If you like first person shooter games you already own bad rats, if you don't you are missing out on one of the most brilliant game of this century.

Final verdict

Pros
Immersive environments
Balanced multiplayer
Overwhelming amount of content
Gorgeous Graphics
Revolutionizes the FPS genre
Fantastic and inspiring story
Great voice acting
Like Half Life 3 but better

Cons
Too much graphics

10/10

92016942.review:
I cannot describe how enlightening this game is. I was once  homeless and starving on the streets before a man walked up to me and said "hey kid, want to battle me in a game of bad rats?". Of course, I was confused at first. "What is bad rats?" The man gave me a sly smirk and adjusted his fedora and went "How about you find out, kiddo?" I was sketched out at first. Who was this man asking me to battle him in a game of bad rats? Little did I know this was the turning point in my life. This man was an angel from heaven. We went to the local library and booted up the old desktop. Thankfully bad rats runs on low graphics so it is accessible for everyone because bad rats doesn't discriminate (besides against dirty cats but they deserve it). He opened the game and let me look at all the rats. Never did I know there were so many rats in existence. It taught me the diversity of rats and about their culture. It was truly eye opening. As I set the totally not racist bomber rat down and attached a balloon to the batter bat, I felt the gears turning in my mind and I realized I love rats and I love physics. The man and me played bad rats every day for years, only encouraging my love for rat physics. I was able to use what I learned from bad rats to write a dissertation on the the aerodynamics and centripetal force offered by rats with a undeniable thirst for cat blood. This research was accepted by Yale University and I received a full scholarship for graduate school and skipped undergraduate. Bad rats made me a genius and now I make a billion dollars a year and can retire at 30 so I can play bad rats for the rest of my life until I die. I hope to be buried with my computer so I can possibly come back as a ghost and keep playing. 

PS. the man and me got happily married and had a bad rats wedding. We named our adopted children Cheesy and Gouda.

91973401.review:
Revolutionary. This game paved the way for the new golden standard of 3D video game design, and ever since the release in 2009, games such as Grand theft auto V, The Witcher 3, The Last of Us, and Skyrim have tried to attempt to mock this games deep lore and gameplay that has aged like a fine wine... but none of them have succeeded. Part of this is due to Bad Rats surreal world building, scattered throughout the world you will see empty boxes of pizzas, graffiti, and a general feeling of the environment being in a state of decay, the rats are no longer in their prime, their underworld has fallen apart due to the rise of household cats. The world building is so strong that you don’t need to be told to kill the cats, you just know that that is what you are here to do and I think that is so gosh dang deep. Speaking of deep, let’s get into the character design:
Games such as Grand theft Auto V are praised for the use of swapping between characters while in the midst of combat, although this game had done it 4 years prior and LEAGUES better!
Gta has you swap between 3 relatively unique main characters to play as, meanwhile Bad Rats boasts 35 different rats to play as all with extremely different and unique abilities at their disposal.
Lastly, I want to point out that this games soundtrack is just superb, it really gives me this feeling that my pack of rats is tucked away in the back of a garage while a high school punk band is performing and some teens are doing the sex RIGHT ABOVE BATTLEFIELD 💯💯

Overall I give this game a 10/10, games have been trying to catch up with this game technologically for years and the only one that has done it is Bad Rats: The Show.

91412502.review:
How can I explain this game without spoiling any of its content...

Imagine you have a cake. It's pink and white and layered with strawberries so you kind of already know what to expect. Sure, there are some hints of chocolate icing here and there that suggests there might be a little bit more to it, but overall it seems quite simple.
And sure enough it is. You take a bite here, and another forkfull there, and all you can taste is the sweetness of the strawberry and the light fluffiness of the cream. The chocolate icing makes its way onto your tongue every now and then, but it's all within the realms of expectations. You decide to push forward a little more, dig in a little deeper.
But something's wrong, and you sure did not anticipate this. Thick caramel sauce starts oozing out from the centre, dragging little chunks of honeycomb with it. You realise that the strawberry and vanilla cream you've been tasting all this time has been but a pretense for what it really hid inside. You try to soak up the caramel with the outer layer of the cake, but it's no use; eventually the caramel drenches everything into mushy, sticky mess. And boy, is it glorious.
You come into the experience expecting something light, but you come out having swallowed the heaviest dessert you've ever had. And the combination somehow works.

91094382.review:
[h1][b]A puzzling nightmare?[/b][/h1]
Sometimes, I disagree about the overall score of certain games, whether they are overly positive or negative. It puts me in the minority and forces me to think about how, and mainly why, people like or dislike such titles. This happens to be [b]Bad Rats[/b]’ case too. While this puzzle game does not have any redeeming qualities, it is still somehow popular enough despite being badmouthed for its gameplay.

However, I found out that [b]Bad Rats[/b] are favoured purely because of one reason. Memes. Case closed.

That leaves people like me in slight confusion, though. How should I know what it is about and if it is actually a competent experience if everyone makes fun of it? Sure, that fact alone could imply that there is not anything good about it. That is not enough for me, as I would like to find out by myself. Well, let us finally dive into this quite a short review. 
[h3][b]The best-laid schemes of rats and cats…[/b][/h3]
What is [b]Bad Rats[/b] about then? You need to figure out how to move a ball to the other end of the level, where it is supposed to hit a tool, such as a shotgun, which would proceed to kill an unsuspecting cat. Well, that is all. There is no story, and this gameplay loop remains the same for the whole game. While it might sound like an unchallenging experience, beware that the opposite is true.

The ball will not move on its own, though. You need to use one of your wilful rats, such as the one with a baseball bat, to hit this round object and make it move. What if there is suddenly an obstacle in your way, as even a sudden high wall might prove to be a stumbling rock to your progress. That is the time when the sheer variety of rodents and items comes to play. Perhaps a trampoline would do the trick or a rat with a vacuum cleaner, who pulls up the ball with it? Maybe an explosion from a suicide bomber would move it across? As you can see, the choices are pretty unique and even quite hilarious.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2470391530
While this approach might sound straightforward, the levels naturally become more difficult as you progress. The maps get more complex, so you will have to think about what combinations of rodents and items might work. I found this appealing enough, as it somehow forced me to discover the most effective and fastest way, which would lead me to a joyful victory.

[h1][b]I am in incredible pain…[/b][/h1]
If everything would work flawlessly, then I would not actually mind recommending [b]Bad Rats[/b]. However, there are several issues, which made my experience rather tiresome. Firstly, the visuals kinda put me off, as they are just bland and fuzzy. Secondly, the music is very repetitive, and I would swear that there are only one or two compositions. Now to the worse part.

The very first problem would be the game’s physics, especially the ball’s one. Even with the right combination of rats, its movement might be completely random, as it will suddenly jump around more than usual, or it will refuse to move further at all. I even witnessed it go through the walls several times, which started to annoy me quite soon. This problem forced me to restart some levels dozens of times before the ball finally decided to behave and reach its destination. The way the physics behave is just atrocious, and it totally ruined the bits of enjoyment I tried to have with this title.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2470396175
Apart from that, I had several technical issues, as [b]Bad Rats[/b] crashed numerously for me. Due to that, I even lost a bit of my progress at times, and there was no error message whatsoever. Perhaps my computer decided to stop my suffering by closing that app. Keep in mind that there are no autosaves, so I advise you to save at the start of every level. I mean, I would suggest you not to play this game at all due to these issues, but you do you. At times, my useable rats and equipment did not even load, so I could not interact with the levels at all, so I had to restart it. Again. I would not mind if it would happen twice or thrice, but as it was a reoccurring issue, it started to piss me off.

That would be all, as there are no other mechanics or a story to follow. While I have to admit that the aspects revolving around rats and their variety is quite good, this title as a whole is just a tremendously broken mess due to the abovementioned issues.

[b]PC Specs and Performance[/b]
[quote]I played it with an [b]i5 8300H[/b], [b]GTX 1060 6GB[/b], and [b]16GB RAM[/b], at highest settings, at [b]35[/b] frames per second, at [b]1240x1024[/b] resolution. Higher resolutions are not available.[/quote]

90606228.review:
By the time I came home from my 9 to 5 job at 711 I had lost all hope. I'm going to slave away at this shitty job straight through my 20's and until I'm dead, I thought. Before I discovered this game, video games had long ceased to be entertaining, only serving as a task to keep me preoccupied with fake rewards to distract from my worsening situation in the real world. That is until the game "Badrats" came upon my screen on the steam recommended section. What could this mean? I thought. Are these rats malevolent or simply of low quality? Or perhaps these rats are just in their cause, but are considered "bad" for the way in which they attain their goals. I had lost all of my money long ago, but as it would be near impossible to be in a worse situation than I was, I opened a new credit card in my name to add to my compiling dept. When I decided to purchase bad rats for 49% off at $0.59, I couldn't have possibly predicted what I was getting into, no one could. 

        Badrats breaks new ground in the standards for the video game industry. When I opened Badrats I was instantly hooked, the vast roster of over 10 rats and 40 levels provide hours of fun like you've never had before. The level editor also provides infinite replay value, so you never have to stop playing Badrats. Now that I have Badrats, I've begun acceling in both my private and social life. My ex wife, carol, has called me and wants to get back together. My manager over at 711  caught sight of me whistling the Badrats theme song and spontaneously pointed at me and said "You're gonna be a star, kid!", now I'm working on the set of the Badrats movie in hollywood. Badrats gives more than anyone could ask for from a $1 videogame.

       The world of Badrats is both deeply beautiful, and philosophical. The vast open world landscapes of Badrats are something to behold. From perfectly crafted red brick backgrounds to incredible grey brick backgrounds, and even a cave system as a background once. Badrats never ceases to impress with its utterly stunning scenery.

       Above all else, Badrats is a mirror, in which the reflection encompasses modern day political entanglements in the middle east and the deep rooted systemic racism in America. In Badrats your aim is to kill a cat with rats. But never is the question raised, why does the cat deserve to be killed? How did centuries of slavery and systemic poverty lead to the cat having to commit a crime in order to achieve higher quality of life, but ultimately end up imprisoned? The "bomber rat" also known as the "muslim rat" (most likely a follower of sunni islam) also makes an appearance in Badrats. Carrying an explosive vest that it uses to further the goals of the rats. This clearly pays homage to war on terror, and war in iraq in which sunni rebels took up arms against the government of Iraq and the American invaders. This rat is a deep representation of the ever prolonging of the war on terror.

       Badrats has permanently changed my outlook on our world we all share. I'm on my way to fulfilling my dream of becoming an actor and pro Badrats player, competing at the Badrats International Tournament for a grand total of $2,000,000. It is impossible to truly sum up my love for Badrats in so few words, so instead, I would like to thank the developers, and tell the reader of this review, that you should buy Badrats right now.

10/10!

89609597.review:
At first glance this seems like an innocent indie game concept gone awry, but a second look quickly reveals the Kafkaesque allegories underneath the thin veil. What many players fail to realize is that this entire game is a dystopian view on the reliance many quantum physicists hold on the famous thought experiment, Schrodinger’s Cat. Bad Rats shows, with horrifyingly accuracy, the future of study in physics.

As man-kind grows nearer and nearer to unlocking the secrets of the quantum world, the thought experiment will hinder progress more and more. Bad Rats shows the feline genocide that will soon follow upon the completion of the grand unified theory, for with the paradox of Schrodinger's Cat ever looming within the minds of our greatest physicists, they will resort to running every possible scenario of cat death and life until every possibility is statistically accounted for. With string theory becoming more and more accepted this means that the possibilities are theoretically endless, which the game alludes to in the unforgiving Expert Mode.

Bad Rats is not an example of bad game design. It is a message. It is a warning. Above all else, it is a mission. To warn us all of the impending doom science will wrought upon us. With the united world pouring every resource and man available into research of cat death probability, incessant matter farming for industrial cat cloning and feline teleportation, we will no doubt drive our species to extinction. Our own hubris will very well be our down-fall.

Trust in the Bad Rats, we are not meant to unlock the secrets of the universe.

87965914.review:
We reviewed this game on our podcast: Garbage Game Night, where we try out poorly reviewed games and give them a second chance, either trying to find something the critics missed or enjoy them because they are so bad…

Bad Rats has a reputation that proceeds it. Because of it's low price and notoriety it is a common white elephant gift on steam. Are there worse games? Sure, but this certainly is a bad game. Imagine if you will, a physics based engine in which you can set up a rube goldberg machine, save the positioning, and press play 50 times, and each time results differently. You would say - wow, this is a terrible system in which to expect a user to solve puzzles. You would be correct. Far more correct than this game has ever been, politically, or in the physics realm. What awaits you in Bad Rats? Terrorist rats that will make you remember that strange stretch of time where Jeff Dunham was popular. Some rats you will never use because they are poorly explained. Multiple ways to kill cats who are ALREADY incapacitated. 

We did a [url=https://garbagegamenight.com/bad-rats-pc/]full podcast episode of this[/url] if you're interested in some more backstory, but in short: It's a bad game. It's bad enough you'll enjoy it for a bit, It's frustrating enough that you won't play it for long.

85908042.review:
When i first started playing this game there was just something about it that was truly beautiful its very obvious that the developers put lots of care and passion into this game with gameplay that just feels fun and a story that is hidden beneath the surface. Bad rats is great at making the player feel emotions as when I first started this game i only had one thought, damn these rats are bad and then I started to cry. I cried because the gameplay and the music were just so well put together it was like nothing I have ever seen before.

This game has a hidden story that many people will think that it speaks about society and how these bad rats are viewed as rebels or scoundrels. However this game is actually telling a story about Harriet Tubman and the underground railroad. For generations the rats were enslaved by the cats in a truly awful way, but one day a rat by the name of Benson T. Fredrickson was able to escape death row and taking control of his master Seargent Scritcy Scratchy, Benson was able to open his eyes and see how the things that they were doing was awful. Benson and Scritchy Scratchy started an alliance and vowed to get all rats out of enslavement, thus they started making an underground railroad in the sewer system, a place where cats dared to go.

Almost nine months later Benson and Scritchy Scratchy were finally done the underground railroad, The two friends then went back up to the surface and started work on sneaking out all the rats. This went smoothly for a good while but as predicted the cats soon caught on to the plan and began to suspect that there was something going on. The cats increased security on the Rats and Benson and Scritchy scratchy only had one thing left to do. Start a revolution.

Benson and Scritchy Scratchy snuck in to where most of the rats were being held and informed the rats of the plan. The next morning the rats started rioting against the evil clutches of the cat folk. Under the command of Benson and the power of Scritchy Scratchy the rats were able to overpower the masses of cats forcing them to retreat to a place that they would never go, the sewers. Benson and Scritchy scratchy have been taking torture devices from the cats and hiding them in the sewers, little did they know they would be able to use them against the cats.

That is where this game starts off, The player plays as a group of Rebel rats who have to show the cats just what they have been through, the strategy in this game is quite difficult as to show the struggle of the rats who are trying to fight for their freedom and be seen as equal to the cat folk.

85247217.review:
At first glance this seems like an innocent indie game concept gone awry, but a second look quickly reveals the Kafkaesque allegories underneath the thin veil. What many players fail to realize is that this entire game is a dystopian view on the reliance many quantum physicists hold on the famous thought experiment, Schrodinger’s Cat. Bad Rats shows, with horrifyingly accuracy, the future of study in physics.

As man-kind grows nearer and nearer to unlocking the secrets of the quantum world, the thought experiment will hinder progress more and more. Bad Rats shows the feline genocide that will soon follow upon the completion of the grand unified theory, for with the paradox of Schrodinger's Cat ever looming within the minds of our greatest physicists, they will resort to running every possible scenario of cat death and life until every possibility is statistically accounted for. With string theory becoming more and more accepted this means that the possibilities are theoretically endless, which the game alludes to in the unforgiving Expert Mode.

Bad Rats is not an example of bad game design. It is a message. It is a warning. Above all else, it is a mission. To warn us all of the impending doom science will wrought upon us. With the united world pouring every resource and man available into research of cat death probability, incessant matter farming for industrial cat cloning and feline teleportation, we will no doubt drive our species to extinction. Our own hubris will very well be our down-fall.

Trust in the Bad Rats, we are not meant to unlock the secrets of the universe.

84875193.review:
[h1] Bad Rats : when you gaze into the abyss, the abyss gazes back [/h1]

You don't even need to start it to feel that this game (should I say masterpiece ?) rises above its peers; the deceptively simple title "Bad Rats" and the already classic artstyle hide a treasure in impressive game design and rich storytelling that a keen eye will immediately perceive. 

From the get go , on the main menu, you can bear witness to the genius of the developers : a mouth-breething idiot would tell you that the game starts in the "[i]wrong"[/i] resolution but , as anyone with half a brain can tell, this is actually intended. By allowing you to try to adjust the resolution of the game to your screen, the game is telling you that you have to [i]"adjust your way of thinking to the game"[/i], a stroke of genius that will surprises even those familiar with the works of other visionaries such as Hideo Kojima or Yoko Taro. This has already filtered the simplest minds, unable to grasp this concept but this goes further.
I spent 10 minutes trying to fit the game to my screen's resolution,  and that's when it hit me : it's backwards, I have to fit my screen to the game ! I need to format myself  in order to be worthy ! In order for the window to fit, I have to think differently.  My mind was blown a second time and I needed to pick up the pieces.

I was presomptuous, I wasn't ready at all . I thought my diploma in Gender studies would have prepared me for anything that life could throw at me... I was deeply and utterly wrong.
I will need to find myself through deep introspection before even attempting to press the "Play" button again. I fear doing so before being ready would destroy my psyche again, beyond repair. 

I recommend this game to anyone willing to have a life-changing experience. Be warned that your life's paradigm may very well be shattered for the low price of 99 cents. 


[u]Dean Takahashi for Polygon[/u]
