54757023.review:
[h1]A genie grants you immortality under the condition you choose one possible but improbable way you can be killed. What is your immortality loophole?[/h1]

I like this one because one day, you decide you don't want to live anymore and go on another mortal-life-long mission to complete each game, finding new purpose for life in your attempt to die.

Then, just as you're about to best the last game, the final collectible in your grasp, you look around, and somewhat reluctantly close the game.

You step away from your computer for the first time in years, desk surrounded by filth and trash. You walk out of your room to see the seaside ranch home you purchased after your third-lifetime as a successful musician--whose career was cut short by a tragic diving accident and your body never recovered--untouched by the years.

You walk around your extravagant home. Attend to all the collectibles an immortal life has brought you, material possessions filling your home. No, your house. This hasn't been a home in years.

You decide to go outside, your age and physical status that of an active 30-something, even though you're well over 200 years old. Your first walk in decades.

Is it really time? Has that day come? What was the rest of the world like? What year was it? Does it matter? You want to die, don't you?

You make it back to the house around dawn. It's cold on the coast this time of year, but the weather has never fazed you, not even when you did that river float in Alaska with only your backpack and a small raft. You're not hungry, though you never have been before, even though you studied under Italy's top chefs just over 50 years ago. You don't feel like sleeping, even though you haven't in about a decade.

So what do you want to do?

You sit back at your desk as the sun begins to rise over the ocean, a large window specifically facing east--a very important detail two lifetimes ago when you had this place built. How many sunrises have you seen now?

It doesn't really matter, does it? The past thousand or so have only fueled the drive to finish those thousand games. What do you want to do? You ask yourself this, a question you've previously had no problem answering. But now..

You slouch in your chair and look down at your shirt, something you'd imagine would be in a worse state by now, having not changed for god knows how long. You sit as the sun rises. The light shines on your face. As you glare against the sun, ready to close the curtains as you've done countless times before.

And it hits you. The sun on your face, muscles activated after so long. You feel it. You're ready. This is the lifetime culmination you've been working toward for so long. It's this moment. You boot up the game, reload the save, and prepare yourself.

You print off the letter you prepared in Word 2000. Or was it 2020? Oh well. Someone would eventually find this place and would want to know what happened to this man who lived a hundred lives.

You lay the letter down on the table in your foyer. You wouldn't want someone to walk in and see whatever lies behind your bedroom door unprepared. Hundreds of years of life can't culminate into a pretty death.

You find your way back to your desk. The sun is shining now, but that's ok. For some reason, it feels good today. Today is a new day, and tomorrow.. tomorrow, that will finally not be the case.

You look at the screen. The hidden easter egg sitting just in front of you. Just one button from no tomorrow. It's time.

You reach out and grab it. 100/100 collectibles found. You sit back. Smile. The time has come. You're ready.

The game flourishes it's congratulations, but.. nothing happens. This can't be.. This was supposed to be the moment. You save, close the game, and go to Steam. "100% Completion" This was supposed to be it.

What could have gone wrong?

You pour over the list in your library. A list you haven't checked in years after installing each and every game when you decided to make this final push. 18TB of every type of game on Steam imaginable.

You check the list. Games: 1094. Installed: 1093.

You spend the next 15 minutes checking for that one grayed out name. The one thing standing between you and your final choice.

Bad Rats. A gag gift from your friend that cost $0.13 during the Steam Summer Sale back in 2013. You remember the exact inscription from all those years ago.

"Now this shit game will be in your library forever. Cheers, fucker. --Titus"

You sit back, and you cry. You cry because you can't manage anything else, the first feeling in what must be decades. You laugh, you stand up and throw your chair to the ground, tears of joy streaking your face. It feels so incredible. So intoxicating.

After the shock settles, the realization hits.

Do you really want to die? You sure as hell don't want to play Bad Rats. No. Maybe this life needs one more chance.

You made it worth it before, didn't you? You took a step back and decided what you were going to make your life out to be, you committed to it, your life, to love, to experience. You can do it again.

You click the start button on your desktop. Your home screen one of your photographs from one of your many world tours. India. Maybe that's where you'll start. Who knows where? Who cares? It doesn't really matter, does it?

You click shut down.

53008677.review:
Level 1: Story - In Bad Rats, you play as Bad Rats as they attempt to have their revenge against the Good Cat for the Great Rat Cleansing of 1945, many rats lost their lives and loved ones to the Good Cat's cruel methods and its up to you to put an end to his reign of terror. The story is short and sweet, not too simple to be boring, but not too complex to be frustrating; to quote Hannah Montana: "It's the best of both worlds."

Level 2: Presentation - Bad Rats uses 3D models with highly detailed textures to craft its deeply atmospheric setting, every level is drenched in dulled greys, browns and oranges, a cage of brick and cement surrounds every room, the rats' eyes emote with much hesitation, each rat appears more traumatised and distant than the last, like their lives have been filled with nothing but torment and suffering. The soundtrack reflects the overwhelming sense of weariness and desperation that the rats evoke, consisting of heart-pumping country-rock and blues melodies that pierce your ears and resonate straight though your mind and veins, shaking your very being to its core, forcing you to feel the pain and anguish that these brave rats must feel on the field of battle; to quote Rob Parissi: "Play that funky music, white boy."

Level 3: Gameplay - To play Bad Rats, all you need is a mouse and keyboard and you're good to go, a wide variety of rats are at your disposal and its up to you to assemble the best team required to take down the feline menace. The game-feel is as fluid as the very blood that spills from the Good Cat's corpse each and every time you kill him with a very small sponge ball. Dragging, dropping and rotating the rats feels buttery-smooth, the physics are 1:1 with real life and it really makes you feel like a bad rat. My favourite rat has got to be the Rocket Rat, the majestic way he flies through the air shines a small, but brilliant light of hope for freedom from the villain's tyranny that, quite frankly, I haven't seen executed with such grace and thematic impact in any other game I've ever played. To quote Jimmy Neutron's dad: "Rockets are flying things."

Level 4: Final Level - Upon entering the final level, it is revealed that the Good Cats you've been murdering in every level of the game up until this point were actually genetically modified rats the entire time and that the real Good Cat has been using the rats' dead bodies to form his Good Cat army to invade and take over the nations of the world in order to implement his Good Cat utopia. Having learnt of the Good Cat's manipulation and wrought with anger, the Bad Rats launch their final all-out assault on the Good Cat to destroy his evil regime, once and for all. This level throws everything at you: slopes, tilting platforms, threatening graffiti; its the final test of your wit and determination. With enough planning, intuition and courage, you can guide the ball to the ultimate button, decapitate the Good Cat and allow the souls of the fallen rats to finally rest in peace. To quote Morgan Freeman: "Get busy living or get busy dying."

Level 5: Completion Bonus - As if the experience of playing and completing 45 masterfully crafted levels wasn't reward enough, for completing every level in Bad Rats, you receive the BAD RATS' KING achievement and the Super Nails, both of which are extremely satisfying rewards to obtain and use. It's not a lot, but its more than enough for a perfect gift to give players who master the game mechanics and are able to perfect their Bad Rats skills. To quote Al Pacino: "Say hello to my little friend."

Level 6: The Struggle - There's no point in hiding it, Bad Rats is a masterpiece. Everything from the story to the visuals to the music to the gameplay is sublime perfection. Never have I played a game so fun and so challenging with a story so simple, yet so unabashedly compelling. Bad Rats was an absolute joy to complete and with that in mind guys, I give this game my completionist rating of... 'Complete It'. To quote Sir Francis of the Filth: "I saw a cat get murdered in the street and I got an erection."

52717804.review:
A lot of games make a big deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation. You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your post apocalyptic journey. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Bad Rats worth playing--and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized. 
This focus is obvious from the first hour of the game, in which character creation and story exposition are beautifully woven together. It's an introduction best experienced on your own rather than described in detail here, but it does set up Bad Rat's framework. Truly a game unmatched by any on the market today, old or new, and worthy of every last praise it has received. 

7.8/10 Too many rats.

52236711.review:
What can be said about this that hasn't been said already? I frankly don't know.

To add to some things other people have said, the game itself is abysmal. Genuinely awful. I played The Incredible Machine 2 when I was a wee babby and that was a great Rube Goldberg puzzler because it was entirely 2D.

This isn't. This is 2.5D. Which means objects can move on the Z-axis, toward or away from the player. In turn, this means objects can roll off the track, something that is not present in TIM2 or even Contraption Maker here on Steam. In my opinion that is enough to mark this as a failure of physics puzzlers. That's not even mentioning the oddly violent deaths that cats suffer, or some of the bizarre costume choices for rat "puzzle objects".

But I recommend Bad Rats to both contribute to the meme that's gone on for a while now, and because there are unironically at least three meta uses for the game: 

1. If you get trading cards to drop, you can sell them for more than the price of the game when it goes heavily on sale, actually making you a few cents.

2. Have a laugh as you spend a few dollars sending it to friends when it's on sale, justifying the poor decisions of the developers for the same price as a cup of coffee from your favorite place that sells the stuff.

3. It works for many requirements tied to Steam sales or events, ranging from "Launch a game you haven't played in a while" to "Write a review for a game". And in the case of the latter, the game is so steeped in its own refuse that you don't actually need to put that much effort into writing the review or worry about the impact your words might have on someone reading it. After all, it's Bad Rats!

(The first half of this review is serious though, if you wanna drop the money on it feel free but I'd say just look up gameplay if you're morbidly curious about what it's actually like.)
